awd_titl_txt: Cyclization Strategies and Methodologies Toward the Synthesis of Complex Natural Products
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Chemical Synthesis (SYN) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor David Williams of Indiana University (IU-Bloomington) will develop new methods and strategies for the construction of complex, bio-active molecules.  These concepts are important for two principal reasons.  There is a need to devise more efficient procedures for the assembly of molecular complexity while finding environmentally benign reagents and reactions.  Secondly, there is need to expand the limits of structural chemistry to identify new scaffolds that are biologically active, both as a tools for chemical biology and as potential hit or even lead compounds for medicinal chemistry.  Multi-step synthesis pathways will be explored for the preparation of bio-active natural products; this project is especially focused on metal-catalyzed cyclization reactions of reactive compounds as a feature that may lead to the formation of two or more rings in a single reaction.  Educational aspects of this project are geared to broadly develop students as problem-solvers in the field of organic chemistry.  Most of the graduates from this laboratory experience are employed in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industries.  Societal benefits will include the recruitment and participation of under-represented individuals and women in all aspects of the research.  Summer research opportunities will also be available for undergraduate participants in this research project. 

This research project seeks to forge new ground in synthetic methodology and particularly in strategies for cyclization reactions.  Transition metal-catalyzed reactions of strained cyclopropanes and cyclopropenes will be explored as a key element in the design of new pathways for the synthesis of complex, bio-active natural products.  The proposed activities are expected to advance knowledge regarding the synthesis of substituted cyclopropanes and the effective incorporation of these reactive building blocks into complex molecular architectures.  These investigations will also examine the propensity for reorganization of small ring metallacycles to form more stable pi-allyl metal intermediates in cyclization processes.  Project objectives seek to devise a reaction cascade concluding with intramolecular [3+2] and [2+2+1] cyclizations.  Studies are also planned on reaction scope and stereoselectivity through the examination of electronic and steric factors imposed by the catalyst and its ligands.  New synthesis strategies are proposed for the efficient  construction of tricyclic cyathanes and fusicoccanes, as well as for completion of the synthesis of daphnicyclidin A.   The project is a significant component of the Indiana University Department of Chemistry STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) commitment with an emphasis on access for women and underrepresented individuals through the IU ACS Bridging Program.  Broader scientific impacts are expected through planned collaborations with scientists in allied disciplines including biology, animal sciences, neuroscience and medicine.  Overall, this project aims to advance fundamental organic chemistry methodology and strategy and to provide a superior platform for student training in modern synthetic chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

                  The project explores concepts of [3+2] and [4+3] cycloaddition reactions for the synthesis of five- and seven-membered ring molecules which feature a number of complex functionalizations.  A series of new methods have been devised for organic synthesis and the applications of these methods have been demonstrated in the construction of pathways to bioactive natural products including cyathanes, daphnicyclidins, and leiodelide anticancer antibiotics.

                  Broader impacts are also readily apparent through collaborations with scientists in allied disciplines including biology, animal sciences, neuroscience, and medicine.  Several of the ad hoc collaborations of the prior award period will continue, and we anticipate additional efforts due to the high level of interest in the cyathanes as agents for studies of dementia and chronic pain.  Collaborative studies of fusicoccanes are also expected as the contributions of organic chemistry are integrated into a significant interdisciplinary investigation.  The applications described in this proposal are well chosen for high impact areas of interest and the potential for addressing specific afflictions such as Alzheimer’s disease, chronic pain, and various cancers.  Overall, the proposed project will advance fundamental organic chemistry with far-reaching implications to benefit society and human health.

                  During the prior project award, seven individuals, including three women, completed their graduate degrees based on the previous studies.  The proposed plan will, directly or indirectly, support the education of seven predoctoral students currently in the laboratories.  This project is a significant component of our STEM commitment with an emphasis on access for women and underrepresented individuals.  This NSF program has continued a longstanding policy of professional training and scientific inquiry in an attractive learning environment.  The Department of Chemistry participates in the GEM Fellowship Program, the McNair Scholars Program, and the CIC Outreach Program to support African-American and Hispanic graduate students.  We have been awarded the ACS Bridging Program Grant and Indiana University is one of 23 national AGEP alliances funded by NSF.  All graduate students participate in research symposia of the local NOBCCHE Chapter (National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers).  Two predoctoral students were selected speakers at the ACS National Graduate Symposium. This award has continued STEM participation for undergraduates.  Approximately 2-3 undergraduates will receive advanced training and study in the laboratories each year.  During this project, three outstanding chemistry students continued their postgraduate education, and another aligned with our lab has received the Goldwater Fellowship.  

                  Another area of broad impact is represented by the fruitful collaborations which stem from this NSF project.  Our involvement with scientists in other disciplines, including biology, animal sciences, neuroscience and medicine is expected to continue.  There is a high level of interest in harnessing the capabilities of organic synthesis to address questions in allied sciences.  Our collaboration with Dr. Joseph Wallace in the Department of Bioengieering and IU School of Medicine regarding agents that improve bone integrity has become an independently funded project.  However, an ad hoc collaborative effort with Professor Milos Novotny and the IU Center for Pheromone Research will continue, and a recent collaboration with Dr. Richard Carpenter (IU-Biology) will investigate inhibition of human transcription factor HSF1.  We anticipate additional efforts due to the high level of interest among neurochemists regarding the cyathanes as agents for studies of dementia and chronic pain.  Collaborative studies of fusicoccanes are also expected as the contributions of organic chemistry rare integrated into a significant interdisciplinary investigation to explore signaling agents and the potential use in studies of cancers.  The applications described in this proposal are well chosen for high impact area of interest and potential for studies to address Alzheimer’s, chronic pain, and various cancers.

                  Professional service also contributes to a broader impact for this NSF program.  The PI has completed his service as the Executive Secretary of the International Society of Heterocyclic Chemistry and distributes a monthly bulletin of ISHC members’ activities.  This PI was also elected as the American Co-Chair of the French-American Chemical Society, with organizational duties for the FACS XVII meeting in 2018 (Orléans, France) and the FACS XVIII in Charleston, SC, USA.

                  In summary, this NSF program greatly contributed to my capabilities as an effective teacher, author and internationally-recognized scholar in organic chemistry.  The broader impacts suggest societal benefits of a diverse and skilled scientific community.  The fundamental advances we seek may have far-reaching implications for new materials, new medicines and benefits for human health.


Last Modified: 07/25/2024
Modified by: David R Williams

Project Outcomes


The project explores concepts of [3+2] and [4+3] cycloaddition reactions for the synthesis of five- and seven-membered ring molecules which feature a number of complex functionalizations.A series of new methods have been devised for organic synthesis and the applications of these methods have been demonstrated in the construction of pathways to bioactive natural products including cyathanes, daphnicyclidins, and leiodelide anticancer antibiotics.


Broader impacts are also readily apparent through collaborations with scientists in allied disciplines including biology, animal sciences, neuroscience, and medicine.Several of the ad hoc collaborations of the prior award period will continue, and we anticipate additional efforts due to the high level of interest in the cyathanes as agents for studies of dementia and chronic pain.Collaborative studies of fusicoccanes are also expected as the contributions of organic chemistry are integrated into a significant interdisciplinary investigation.The applications described in this proposal are well chosen for high impact areas of interest and the potential for addressing specific afflictions such as Alzheimers disease, chronic pain, and various cancers.Overall, the proposed project will advance fundamental organic chemistry with far-reaching implications to benefit society and human health.
